bibl.title: Letter from John R. Kissinger to Philip Showalter Hench, March 15, 1941

div1.p: Kissinger complains about the conflicting stories concerning the yellow fever experiments. He discusses his willingness to participate in the human experiments.

div1.head: Letter from John R. Kissinger to Philip Showalter Hench, March 15, 1941
div1.opener:
St. Petersburg
R2 box 1332
Florida
Mar, 15/41
Dr Philip S Hench
Rochester
Min.
My Dear Doctor
div1.p:
Your card just received I
was surprised that it was sent to Huntington
for I thought you had my adress down
here.

I am sorry that I will have to wait
till I get back home (later part of April
to see the item about myself you sent,
After reading and hearing so many
conflicting storys, of the Yellow Fever
experiment. I wonder if I was there at
the time,

It is to bad that Major Walter Reed was
not permited to live.

It seems that so many have shot up
that know all about that experment
that it make me think how little I know
I was around with Reed & the other Doctors,
everyday from June 1900 untill Feb 8 1901.
and I was in the First goup of eight to
have the mosquetos put on them,

Doctor Reed knew that I stood ready to
be experimented on at any time and he
got permit from my superior Officers,
long befor we went to Camp Leazer
that why they put the mosquetos on
me the first day we wer there because
I had not left Camp Columbia 30 days
befor by Reed request.

Now Doctor I hope you will pardon
me for making this slatement, I wish
to take no glory from John J Moran
and I feel that he is entitled to it
as far as his volunteering.

But I am geting a little peaved that
they are having me trailing him.
For I was in it befor he ever though of going
in.

Doctor General Truby has about the
clostes to the truth as any one I have
heard from.

I think that if Truby and I could get
to gether and compare notes, our
storys would be about the same

I received two beautfuly painting
from Wyeth Bro, and I understand
they are going to take up Major Reed
and his experment for there next
issue.

We are having cold weather down
here this winter, and Mrs Kissinger
and I have not been feeling the best
I think this will be our last winter
down here for a while.>

I hope Doctor you will not misunder-
stand me and begin to think I am
trying to be a know it all, or taking
to much credit up on my self.

But credit or no credit I am glad I was
permited to have a small part in
that experment.

I regret that my education will not
permit me to expess myself as I would
like to, for I am afraid that I am
missunderstood

Hoping you and Mrs Hench has had
a plesent winter.

Mrs Kissinger joins me in wishing
you and Mrs Hench the best and our love,
div1.closer:
Your sincerely John R Kissinger.
P. S. will be at home the last of
April.
